Literature Review: Respiratory viruses, particularly influenza viruses, pose a significant threat to global public health due to their ability to cause widespread morbidity and mortality through seasonal epidemics and sporadic pandemics. Influenza viruses are primarily transmitted through three main routes: direct contact, indirect contact via contaminated surfaces (fomites), and inhalation of expelled aerosols. Each of these transmission modes is influenced by a complex interplay of viral, environmental, and host factors, which can be targeted by various interventions to mitigate the spread of the virus. Influenza viruses are enveloped RNA viruses that belong to the family Orthomyxoviridae. They are classified into four types: A, B, C, and D, with types A and B being the most clinically relevant for human infections. Influenza A viruses are further divided into subtypes based on the surface glycoproteins hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA). The HA protein is responsible for binding to host cell receptors, while the NA protein facilitates the release of newly formed virions from infected cells. The genetic variability of influenza viruses, driven by antigenic drift and shift, contributes to their ability to evade host immune responses and maintain their transmissibility. Modes of Transmission: Direct Contact, Indirect Contact (Fomites), Airborne Transmission. Natural Barriers to Transmission. Nonpharmaceutical Interventions: Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), Environmental Modifications, Behavioral Changes. Pharmaceutical Interventions: Vaccines, Antiviral Drugs. Conclusion: Influenza viruses pose a significant public health challenge due to their ability to transmit efficiently through multiple routes. Understanding the mechanisms of transmission and the factors that influence it is crucial for developing effective interventions to mitigate the spread of the virus. Natural barriers, nonpharmaceutical interventions, and pharmaceutical interventions all play important roles in reducing the transmission of influenza viruses. By combining these strategies, it is possible to significantly reduce the burden of influenza and protect vulnerable populations from the disease.
